众所周知，医生不愿意挂起听诊器。但在每个医生的职业生涯中，他们的技能都会衰退，温和的推动对他们和他们的病人来说是最好的事情。这同样适用于金融界的隐喻医生，他们诊断市场健康状况的能力会随着时间的推移而变化。现在，对于所有此类医生中最杰出的一位：科珀博士来说，末日可能即将来临。

铜是一种对制造各种配件、管道和电线至关重要的金属，由于其作为全球工业健康状况的风向标的作用，在华尔街赢得了这个绰号。铜价飙升被视为经济复苏的早期迹象；大幅下降是经济衰退的预兆，或者至少是制造业衰退的预兆。

那么目前发生了什么？制造业看起来正处于高峰期。全球工业产值同比仅增长0.5%，远低于过去二十年2.6%的平均水平，发达国家正处于工业衰退之中。 2015 年类似规模的波动导致铜价暴跌约四分之一。但今年到目前为止，它们仅下降了 6%。 2025 年到期的期货持平，2026 年到期的期货则略有上涨。

通常经验法则的崩溃在中国最为引人注目，中国消耗了全球每年铜供应量的一半以上。其房地产市场的低迷可能会让你认为这种金属注定会失败。毕竟，曾经是铜需求主要驱动力的房地产投资同比下降了9%。但奇怪的是，今年中国对这种金属的需求增长了 10% 左右。

对此的解释在于能源系统正在发生根本性的转变。据高盛银行称，中国今年将安装约 150吉瓦的铜密集型太阳能产能，几乎是去年安装量的两倍。储存能量的方法也需要金属。抽水蓄能水电就是一个例子。这涉及将水从一个水库移至另一个水库，以储存风能和太阳能的多余能量或将其释放。中国已经拥有世界水力发电容量的30%，达到50吉瓦。另外89吉瓦的产能正在建设中，这将需要大量的铜。

其他国家也在绿色转型上投入巨资，并制定立法以增加对金属的需求。金融数据公司标普全球表示，到 2035 年，精炼铜的需求将几乎翻倍，达到 4900 万吨。电池、能源传输、太阳能电池、运输——都需要金属。一辆电动汽车含有超过 50 公斤的材料，是传统汽车用量的两倍多。全球范围内旨在减少排放的新规则将引导消费者转向电动汽车，远离铜灯前辈。欧洲将从 2035 年起禁止销售新型汽油动力汽车。

因此，供应的紧缩将是历史性的，这意味着天价的铜价将不再表明工业机械制造商、建筑公司、电子制造商等的乐观情绪。相反，对铜的需求不断增长将越来越反映出政界人士对更环保能源的渴望，有时也反映出对进口依赖的减少。

在正常情况下，从头开始建设电网至少是未来更大经济活动的信号。然而，能源转型的目的是取代现有活动，而不是增加现有活动。在能源基础设施方面，中国今年新增的太阳能投资在满负荷运行时可产生150吉瓦时的能源，相当于每小时近9万桶石油。中国现在不需要从海外生产商购买这些能源。结果可能对地球有利，但不会对总体经济活动产生太大影响。

随着铜需求的增长被锁定，并且在很大程度上是根据法律指令进行的，随着时间的推移，金属价格将越来越少地反映全球经济状况，而越来越多地反映全球经济状况。能源转型。那么，尽管出于不同的原因，铜价仍然值得关注。想要了解全球经济状况的投资者将被想要了解其绿色政策进展情况的政策制定者所取代。科珀博士的退休可能是一个悲伤的时刻，但这并不是故事的结局。 ■

“卢克·天行者和加密货币领域的达斯·维德。”迈克尔·刘易斯 (Michael Lewis) 是这样描述他的主题与加密货币交易所ftx创始人山姆·班克曼·弗里德 (Sam Bankman-Fried) 的兴衰的。赵长鹏（如图）是竞争对手公司币安的老板。

在班克曼-弗里德的交易所因资产负债表出现 80 亿美元的缺口而崩溃之前，这个类比似乎很恰当。这两个人控制着世界上最大的两家加密货币交易所。两者均以缩写词命名：“ sbf ”和“ cz ”。 sbf 年轻、才华横溢，而且似乎喜欢与监管机构打好关系，他是一位神童，而cz则是他的影子陪衬。为了避免受到国家法律的约束，他的交易所“无处可去”。币安长期以来一直因可能涉嫌洗钱和违反刑事制裁而受到美国司法部的调查。在两人反目成仇之前， cz就投资了ftx 。然后sbf公开刺激cz的法律问题， cz的一条推文可能引发了ftx的挤兑。

现在，随着ftx退出舞台， sbf接受审判，并被指控犯有各种欺诈行为， cz否认了这一点，他看起来很像加密货币领域最后一个站着的人。币安完全主导了加密货币交易（见图表）。其中高达 40-50% 的交易量发生在平台上。 cz于 10 月 11 日在巴林接受《经济学人》采访时讨论的一个大问题是币安现在将如何发展。

自从加密货币交易所存在以来，金融法就一直不适合它们。鉴于所交易资产的性质，它们实际上是交易所、经纪商和结算公司的混合体。如果加密货币交易所在很大程度上不受监管，那至少部分是因为很少有法律来管理它们。

但是，随着ftx的崩溃，情况开始发生变化。世界各地的立法者和监管机构都在急于制定新法律或对该行业进行打击。这对交易所有两大影响。首先，监管机构希望确保他们不会像ftx那样不当处理或不当使用客户资金。其次，他们希望确保交易所不会助长金融犯罪。

cz坚持认为客户可以信任他的交易所。他说，“币安的结构有很多方面与ftx不同。”该公司满足了客户的大量赎回要求，包括在动荡的市场中。他指出，美国金融监管机构证券交易委员会（ SEC ）花了很长时间调查币安的此类不当行为。 cz表示，监管机构可以提供币安混合用户资金的“零证据”，“这实际上有助于我们证明我们没有这样做。”美国证券交易委员会的其他投诉，包括该公司未经许可发行证券，仍有待法庭审理。

然而，对于币安来说，第二个要求可能会更加棘手。 12 月，新闻机构路透社报道称，美国司法部检察官对于是否指控该公司洗钱或违反制裁行为存在分歧。据另一家新闻服务机构彭博社报道，币安于 2021 年撤回了其总部所在地新加坡的持牌交易所申请，部分原因是其无法遵守严格的反洗钱规则。美国证券交易委员会引用了一名前雇员的证据，该雇员承认该公司认为这是一家“未经许可的证券交易所”，并且“永远不想受到监管”。

cz认为这是“前雇员的私人聊天”，并补充说“到目前为止这不是正确的事情”。他指出，币安是“世界上获得许可最多的加密货币公司”，获准在亚洲、欧洲和中东的 18 个国家开展业务（其美国分支机构在 44 个州开展业务）。币安现在似乎与各个当局相处融洽。一位发言人证实，最近几天，为了遵守国际制裁法，该公司冻结了“少数为支持哈马斯募捐的账户”。

该公司现在的测试将在欧洲进行。美国正在打击加密货币，不太可能很快通过新法律。相比之下，欧洲立法者编写了“加密资产市场”或“云母”框架，并于 6 月生效。交易所可以在 2026 年之前继续在现有许可证下运营，除非根据MICA拒绝，这将需要强有力的反洗钱和恐怖主义融资政策。 cz表示，除了这些政策之外，完整的许可证意味着当局会审查“你的钱包基础设施、你的安全、你的客户支持政策、你的退款政策。他们会关注你的整个业务。”

加密货币交易所不能再因为国家规则不存在而辩称它不能遵守国家规则。未能达到欧洲标准将表明币安不愿或无法遵守明确的法律。在《星球大战》中，尤达警告卢克·天行者，转向黑暗面更容易积累或运用力量。在光下操作比较困难。 ■

; Thu, 19 Oct 2023 10:22:49 GMT /内容/si0kahc8pddah089jpq88rvtepg96gsh https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/10/19/will-binance-come-over-to-the-light-side Israel turns to financial weapons as well as military ones

在不到两周的时间里，大约 3,500 名加沙人被杀，12,000 人受伤，超过 100 万人流离失所——美国和联合国正试图代表他们开辟一条进入埃及的通道。该地带的整个街区都被炸成了灰烬。由于食物、水和医疗用品被切断，联合国于 10 月 16 日警告说，加沙 230 万人民正处于“深渊的边缘”。自以色列发动袭击以来，战争几乎耗尽了该领土的所有经济生活来源。

二十年来的大部分时间里，加沙一直依赖国际捐助者的支持来维持其财务生存。 10月18日，以色列总理本雅明·内塔尼亚胡表示，以色列将允许少量食品和药品越过埃及边境进入以色列境内，这将是哈马斯10月7日对以色列发动残酷袭击以来的第一批物资。包括美国在内的以色列盟友正在推动接纳更多人。但与此同时，以色列希望以任何可能的方式窒息哈马斯，这需要使用经济和军事武器。

战前巴勒斯坦经济的悲惨状况使避免人道主义灾难变得更加困难。以色列、加沙和约旦河西岸共享一个市场，由联合国在 1994 年斡旋的一项协议管辖。该协议背后的想法是巴勒斯坦人将在以色列工作，以色列资本将涌入加沙和约旦河西岸，那里的富裕国家回报正在等待。事实上，以色列的限制仍然存在，巴勒斯坦经济仍然依赖施舍。战争前夕，以色列人的平均富裕程度是巴勒斯坦人平均富裕程度的 15 倍。只有三分之一的西岸居民可以使用污水处理系统；大约 10% 的人在没有供水的情况下仍能生存。西岸居民被允许在以色列从事低技能工作，但他们的行动受到严格限制。

在加沙，情况更糟。 2007年至2022年，西岸人均国内生产总值平均每年增长2.8%。同一时期，加沙地区平均变得更加贫穷，当地经济每年萎缩2.5%。自哈马斯 2007 年掌权以来，该地区的运作几乎处于以色列的全面封锁之下。直到最近，该地区的电力仍由以色列提供，但只获得了其所需电力的三分之一。双方在 2008 年、2014 年和 2021 年发生的三场战争中，每场战争都给加沙造成了至少相当于一年的GDP损失。

如果一个经济体无法创造任何东西，那么受到影响的就不仅仅是增长。失业现象普遍存在。到2021年，加沙一半以上的成年人口生活在国际货币基金组织的贫困线以下。赚钱的方法很少。过去的一种方式是通过加沙南部边境下的隧道进行进出口贸易，但埃及在 2014 年与哈马斯发生冲突后清除了大部分。另一种方式是重建战争摧毁的地方。加沙的主要业务之一是建筑业，去年增长了 20%。一旦本轮战争结束，它可能会增长更多。

其他人则将各种外部来源的收入拼凑在一起。尽管管理约旦河西岸的巴勒斯坦权力机构官员于 2007 年被哈马斯赶出了加沙，但巴勒斯坦权力机构 ( PA ) 的工资单上仍有约 70,000 名加沙人，而且他们中没有一个人真正去上班。卡塔尔每月向数千名当地人的银行账户存入现金（约 10 美元）。巴勒斯坦权力机构支付加沙的电费，以色列从代表巴勒斯坦权力机构在西岸征收的税款中扣除这些电费。联合国为30万名加沙儿童提供教育；它与慈善机构合作运营的医院网络为该领土提供基本医疗保健。

该地带的资产

加沙人依赖的另一个组织是哈马斯，其行政部门负责管理加沙地带的政府。自上台以来，哈马斯已将公务员人数从大约 2 万名增加到 5 万名。去年，其支出对GDP增长的贡献率为 0.8%，而所有家庭和企业支出的贡献率为 0.3%。由于慈善机构经营着该地区的许多学校和医院，而巴勒斯坦权力机构也维持运转，哈马斯能够在其他地方大手笔花钱。

它通过巧妙的税收制度为其支出提供资金。尽管加沙没有从以色列进口，但它确实从埃及和约旦河西岸进口，埃及的贸易最近有所增加。哈马斯对穿越埃及边境的食品和燃料征税；从婴儿食品到牛仔裤，占产品价值的 16.5%；渔民捕获的每公斤鱼收费三谢克尔（0.75 美元）；并征收所得税。经济学家总共估计，哈马斯每年可能收受 15 亿谢克尔左右。

其他资金来源已经进入以色列的视线。根据美国的最佳猜测，加沙的各个伊斯兰组织每年可能从伊朗获得 100 美元。哈马斯还收到来自海湾和西方国家的个人捐款，其中一些是使用加密货币偷偷跨境转移的。以色列及其盟友已经尽可能严厉打击这些资金来源，冻结了伊斯坦布尔和伦敦的账户。

对加沙的援助最终会加强哈马斯的地位吗？过去，以色列一直对在该地带开展工作的多边组织持谨慎态度。然而，其他政府发现慈善机构与哈马斯之间的联系很少。在加沙，很少有人相信哈马斯向援助征税的传言。加沙一家智库的老板认为，形势如此严峻，“损失一点燃料是值得的”。

以色列决策者在约旦河西岸也面临着困境。只有几千名加沙人在以色列工作；相比之下，西岸四分之一的劳动力在边境或犹太人定居点工作。以色列确实允许通过西岸进行进出口——该地区的关税约占巴勒斯坦权力机构预算的三分之二。这些税款由以色列征收，有时会在转移前扣留数月。据报道，一些以色列官员希望削减此类付款，要么将资金重新用于加沙重建，要么希望停止向加沙家庭付款。其他以色列官员坚称，巴勒斯坦权力机构需要更多而不是更少的资金来维持脆弱的和平。

在某些方面，以色列政客面临的选择是他们过去面临的选择的夸大版本。当以色列想要遏制哈马斯时，帮助该组织收税是没有意义的。既然以色列想要摧毁哈马斯，那么从军事角度来看，允许物资进入加沙是没有意义的。然而，如果更加严厉地限制物资流动，人道主义灾难就会随之而来。 10 月 17 日，加沙卫生部请求提供发电机。报告称，如果没有他们，医院即将关闭。 ■

乔·拜登在 10 月 18 日闪电访问以色列期间发表的公开声明并未表明对以色列即将入侵加沙地带有太多疑虑。然而，私下里，美国总统的顾问希望就一个紧迫问题向以色列领导人施压：战后应该发生什么？

以色列官员表示，他们的重点是推翻哈马斯权力，以对其 10 月 7 日在以色列南部犯下的大屠杀进行报复。 “加沙将不再对以色列构成威胁，”外交部长埃利·科恩表示。 “我们不会同意哈马斯在加沙拥有任何权力。” 10 月 17 日，加沙阿赫利阿拉伯医院发生致命爆炸，以色列指责巴勒斯坦火箭失手，这说明了在如此人口稠密的地方发生战斗的风险，但以色列宣称的战争目标并未改变。

四路停车

但以色列的战后计划仍然不确定。它有四个主要选项，全都是不好的选项。首先是对加沙的长期占领，就像1967年至2005年那样。以色列军队必须保卫这片飞地，在巴勒斯坦政府缺席的情况下，可能还必须监督基本服务。

这可能会让以色列宗教右翼的一部分感到高兴，他们仍然对 2005 年从加沙撤出所有以色列士兵和定居者感到愤怒，认为这是放弃了犹太人的圣经家园的一小部分。但考虑到沉重的经济负担、可能会出现无休无止的负面报道以及不断出现的人员伤亡，没有人希望看到加沙重新被占领。拜登10月15日警告称，持久占领将是一个“大错误”。大多数以色列战略家都同意这一点。

第二种选择是发动一场战争，斩首哈马斯，然后离开该领土。这可以说是最糟糕的前进方式。哈马斯的一些领导人和支持者可能会出现重组该组织。即使他们不这样做，其他一些不良力量也会取代它。中东地区有激进团体利用不受监管空间的历史。

从以色列的角度来看，最好的结果是巴勒斯坦权力机构（ PA ）的回归，该权力机构与以色列协调管理西岸部分地区。但这条道路充满了障碍。首先是巴勒斯坦总统马哈茂德·阿巴斯不愿意这样做。 “我认为没有人会那么愚蠢，认为他可以骑着以色列坦克返回加沙，”前巴勒斯坦部长加桑·哈提卜说。

即使阿巴斯先生能够以这种方式掌权，他也可能不想这样做。巴勒斯坦权力机构前主席、巴勒斯坦民族主义的长期代表人物亚西尔·阿拉法特 (Yasser Arafat) 对加沙情有独钟。 1994 年获准返回巴勒斯坦后，他在那里住了一段时间。与阿巴斯关系密切的人士表示，相比之下，他将加沙视为一个充满敌意的地方。

加沙几乎肯定会对派来保卫加沙的巴勒斯坦警察怀有敌意。巴勒斯坦权力机构在其安全部门雇用了约 60,000 名员工，其权力覆盖了西岸约三分之一的地区（见地图）。它甚至无法控制这一有限区域：约旦河西岸北部城市杰宁和纳布卢斯的部分地区局势十分动荡，巴勒斯坦权力机构的部队不敢巡逻，以免遭到袭击。士气低落。如果巴勒斯坦警察返回加沙，他们将成为哈马斯、伊斯兰圣战组织和其他武装分子残余分子的目标。 2006年哈马斯赢得议会选举后，哈马斯和巴勒斯坦权力机构在加沙爆发了血腥内战。哈马斯最终获胜，并于2007年将巴勒斯坦权力机构驱逐出加沙地带。

安全也不是唯一的问题。哈马斯上台后，阿巴斯要求加沙的官僚停止工作。哈马斯雇佣了数万名支持者来填补公务员队伍，而巴勒斯坦权力机构则继续向其工人支付工资，让他们坐在家里。保留这种官僚机构意味着要与大约 40,000 名因在意识形态上忠于哈马斯而被雇用的人合作；如果不予考虑，就会重蹈美国在伊拉克“去复兴党化”计划的覆辙，该计划导致大批愤怒的失业者流落街头。

第四种选择是组建某种替代政府，由与以色列和埃及密切合作的当地知名人士组成。以色列一直依赖这种安排，直到 20 世纪 90 年代，之后巴勒斯坦权力机构开始接管被占领土的民事职能。

有人传言试图让在加沙长大的前巴勒斯坦权力机构安全负责人穆罕默德·达赫兰接替哈马斯掌权。但达赫兰先生过去十年一直在阿拉伯联合酋长国（ UAE ）首都阿布扎比度过。他与巴勒斯坦权力机构闹翻了； 2016年，巴勒斯坦法院判定他犯有腐败罪。他和加沙的家人之间也存在不和：2007 年，他领导了针对哈马斯的战斗。“我认为这是一种幻觉，”以色列军队预备役上校、摩西达扬中心 (Moshe Dayan Centre) 的分析师迈克尔·米尔斯坦 (Michael Milstein) 说。特拉维夫智囊团。 “我什至不确定他是否想回来。他担心人们会希望他死。”

达兰先生的案例指出了一个更大的问题。巴勒斯坦人的分裂已经近二十年了。分裂很大程度上是他们的错：尽管哈马斯和巴勒斯坦权力机构领导人每隔几年会面一次，口头上表示和解，但双方都不想妥协。但以色列总理本雅明·内塔尼亚胡的分而治之政策也加剧了分裂，他认为这是阻碍巴勒斯坦独立国家梦想的有用工具。以色列前总理埃胡德·巴拉克表示：“内塔尼亚胡在维持哈马斯活力方面的策略存在缺陷。”

哈马斯和巴勒斯坦权力机构均以一党专制政权统治其小国。 2021 年，阿巴斯先生的批评者尼扎尔·巴纳特 (Nizar Banat) 在希伯伦的家中被巴勒斯坦警察殴打致死。那些在加沙反对哈马斯的人面临着酷刑和处决的危险。大多数巴勒斯坦人选择保持沉默，回避政治并专注于他们的日常斗争。

巴勒斯坦政策和调查研究中心 ( PCPSR ) 的最新民意调查发现，65% 的加沙人将在与阿巴斯总统的正面交锋中投票给哈马斯领导人伊斯梅尔·哈尼亚 (Ismail Haniyeh)（阿巴斯将输掉选举）。西岸也是如此）。哈马斯将在加沙议会选举中赢得 44% 的选票，而阿巴斯的派系法塔赫仅获得 28%。

在岩石和瓦罐之间

乍一看，这表明对哈马斯的持久支持。但此类民意调查只提供了激进分子和无能者之间的二元选择。整整80%的巴勒斯坦人希望阿巴斯先生辞职。医院爆炸发生数小时后，约旦河西岸各城市爆发了抗议活动，示威者高呼：“人民要求总统下台。”他现年 87 岁，没有明确的继任者。他的继任者都没有激发太多热情。

在哈尼亚先生和巴勒斯坦权力机构毫无特色的总理穆罕默德·什塔耶之间的一场假设竞选中，哈尼亚先生将在加沙以 45 分的优势获胜，在约旦河西岸以 21 分的优势获胜。同样，这与其说证明了哈尼亚先生的受欢迎程度，不如说证明了什塔耶先生缺乏受欢迎程度：2019 年哈尼亚上任 100 天后的一项民意调查发现，53% 的巴勒斯坦人甚至不知道他是总理。

开放式问题会产生更有意义的结果。当PCPSR要求巴勒斯坦人选出他们首选的阿巴斯继任者时，多数人表示他们不知道。在约旦河西岸和加沙地带，第二个最受欢迎的答案是马尔万·巴尔古蒂（Marwan Barghouti），他是法塔赫成员，因策划导致以色列平民死亡的恐怖袭击而在以色列监狱服刑，多次被判无期徒刑。其他几位最佳人选，例如达赫兰和前哈马斯领导人哈立德·梅沙尔，甚至不住在巴勒斯坦领土上。

流亡者、囚犯——或者无人：巴勒斯坦政治生活垂死挣扎。巴勒斯坦人将这种令人遗憾的局面归咎于以色列，认为缺乏有意义的和平谈判已经剥夺了巴勒斯坦权力机构存在的理由。 “我认为阿巴斯先生将成为最后一位巴勒斯坦总统，”哈提卜先生说。 “巴勒斯坦权力机构的整体理念是，它是向巴勒斯坦国的过渡。如果没有政治视野，那么整个巴勒斯坦权力机构就变得无关紧要。”

以色列人认为，巴勒斯坦权力机构通过猖獗的腐败行为削弱了自己的地位。过去三十年来，数十亿美元的外国援助被抽走，用于在约旦购买豪华别墅，并充实欧洲的银行账户。当被问及巴勒斯坦社会的主要问题时，更多的人提到自己政府的腐败（25%），而不是以色列的持续占领（19%）。

有足够的责备可以分享。然而，结果是，法塔赫在大多数巴勒斯坦人眼中可能是不可挽回的，一场解放运动变得僵化和颓废。近年来，甚至一些以色列人也开始怀疑哈马斯是否可以成为对话者，重蹈法塔赫几十年前的覆辙，从暴力激进分子转变为温顺的官僚。

哈马斯不仅似乎专注于改善加沙的经济，其一些领导人似乎也愿意接受两国解决方案。对于一个其章程曾经呼吁毁灭以色列的组织来说，这将是一个显着的转变。去年，该组织加沙政治领导层成员巴塞姆·纳伊姆 (Bassem Naim) 告诉本报记者，该组织愿意接受“在 1967 年边界上建立一个国家”。另一位政治官员加齐·哈马德一年前也说过同样的话。

现在看来这样的想法很幼稚。米尔斯坦先生是为数不多的在大屠杀发生前警告哈马斯明显的实用主义只是一个诡计的以色列知名人士之一。他的观点被可怕的事件所证实，现在几乎成为以色列的普遍观点。即使哈马斯愿意参加和谈，愤怒、悲伤的以色列公众也不会成为愿意的伙伴：绝大多数以色列人希望消灭哈马斯，而不是奖励它。

另外两个问题将影响加沙的未来。一是阿拉伯国家将扮演什么角色。在过去一周的私下谈话中，几位阿拉伯官员提出了为这片飞地派遣外国维和部队的想法，但大多数人很快补充说，他们的国家并不急于参与。

埃及在加沙并不受欢迎，一是因为它与以色列一起封锁了该领土，二是因为埃及曾在 1948 年至 1967 年期间担任加沙统治者。阿联酋对于扮演重要角色会犹豫不决。 “我们不会单独行动，”一位阿联酋外交官表示。沙特阿拉伯的情况可能也是如此。

以色列可能会否决卡塔尔这个在加沙最具影响力的国家之一的任何角色。多年来，在以色列的支持下，该酋长国帮助稳定了加沙的经济，每月发放高达 30 美元的福利金、公务员工资和免费燃油。但它对哈马斯的支持——该组织的一些领导人居住在那里——现在将使其受到怀疑。 “过去十年以色列的整体战略就是信任卡塔尔，”米尔斯坦先生说。 “我们应该从这场战争中吸取的教训之一是，我们不应该让卡塔尔再参与其中。”

尽管阿拉伯国家不想保护加沙，但他们可能愿意帮助重建它。 2014 年上一次大战结束后，捐助者承诺提供 35 亿美元用于重建（尽管到 2016 年底他们只支付了其中的 51%）。这次的账单会更大。

另一个问题是PA会发生什么。一半的巴勒斯坦人告诉民意调查机构应该解散。这样做会剥夺他们中许多人的收入（巴勒斯坦权力机构是西岸最大的雇主），并可能导致更多暴力。但这也会增加以色列占领的成本，或许还会迫使巴勒斯坦的长期未来重新回到以色列的政治议程上，而此前的二十年里，这个问题很少被讨论。 “这是他留下的唯一一张牌，”阿巴斯先生的一位前密友说道。

仅针对加沙问题没有持久的解决方案。尽管存在长期分裂，那里的巴勒斯坦人仍然将自己视为更大政体的一部分。无论如何，该地带太小，而且缺乏自然资源，无法自行发展。它的经济依赖于以色列：从草莓农场到家具工厂，一切都依赖于对其富裕邻国的出口。无论谁控制了加沙，作为一个孤立的小国，加沙既不会稳定，也不会繁荣。

为加沙带来持久平静的唯一途径是更广泛地解决以色列-巴勒斯坦冲突。哈提布警告说，如果通过谈判达成解决方案的前景完全消失，“温和的领导层也将随之消失。”以色列可以斩首哈马斯。 But it is far less clear that anything better will take its place. ■

F OR THE first time in more than 40 years, the Israeli Defence Forces ( IDF ) have called up their entire armoured corps, thought to number more than 1,000 tanks. Fully 360,000 reservists have also been mustered, including a civil-defence force of 20,000 people. The additional manpower is intended to bolster the IDF ’s full-time personnel, of roughly 170,000. Although some of these troops are deployed along Israel's northern border, to ward off a potential attack from Lebanon by the militants of Hizbullah, more are massing in the south, near the Gaza Strip. Israel is poised to begin what is expected to be its biggest military operation since the invasion of Lebanon in 1982. Its leaders have said they are determined to destroy Hamas, the militant group that controls Gaza, in retaliation for its bloodthirsty rampage across southern Israel on October 7th.

As The Economist went to press, no assault had materialised. The most obvious reason for the delay was the brief visit to Israel on October 18th of Joe Biden, America's president. His presence was intended both to show support for Israel and to try to broker some sort of agreement to help Palestinian civilians trapped in Gaza.

As it happened, just as Mr Biden was boarding Air Force One on October 17th to head to the region, a deadly explosion racked a hospital in Gaza. The territory's health ministry said that hundreds of people had been killed. Hamas blamed bombing by the IDF . Israel said a rocket fired by another Palestinian militant group, Islamic Jihad, had malfunctioned and fallen on the hospital compound.

Analysis of images and video footage by independent researchers suggested that Israel's explanation was more plausible. The IDF also released tracking data on rocket launches and intercepted communications among Palestinians that appeared to bear out its account. Palestinian rockets are built in makeshift workshops in Gaza to Iranian designs. Mid-air malfunctions are common: the IDF claims that of over 7,000 rockets fired at Israel since October 7th, at least 450 have fallen within Gaza. Israel points out that the images of the explosion's aftermath show a charred car park at the centre of the hospital compound, and lots of damage to adjacent buildings, but no crater or structural devastation of the sort that would be expected from the munitions it uses in air strikes.

Mr Biden backed Israel's version of events. American officials cited their own infra-red satellite data and intercepts as evidence. But the tragedy nonetheless scotched his hopes of reaching a sweeping deal with Arab leaders to get aid into Gaza and at least some civilians out, despite Israel's blockade of the territory.

Timing is all

Any agreement depends on the acquiescence of Egypt, with which Gaza has a short border and where deliveries of food and medical equipment are piling up. But the carnage at the Ahli Arab hospital caused such outrage in the Arab world that Jordan quickly cancelled a summit where Mr Biden was to meet Abdel-Fattah al-Sisi, Egypt's president, and Mahmoud Abbas, the leader of the Palestinian Authority ( PA ).

“There is no point in doing anything at this time other than stopping this war,” said Ayman Safadi, Jordan's foreign minister. In the end the best Mr Biden could do was secure an Israeli pledge not to obstruct aid deliveries and an Egyptian one to let 20 trucks a day into Gaza. He also announced that America itself would provide $100m in aid to ease the Palestinians' plight.

The tragedy at the hospital underlined the slow progress of Israel's effort to encourage Palestinian civilians to move to the southern part of the Gaza Strip to escape the brunt of the looming battle. The IDF says that only 600,000 or so of the 1.1m residents of northern Gaza have heeded its call. By delaying a wide-ranging deal on humanitarian aid or safe zones where civilians can take shelter, the explosion at Ahli Arab will have set back efforts to persuade the holdouts. As it is, more Gazans have already been killed just by Israel's bombing campaign since October 7th than in any previous conflict involving the territory. Inevitably, a ground assault will lead to far more deaths.

Southern Gaza has become extremely overcrowded, with no organised provision of food or shelter for arrivals from the north. Hamas has told Gazans to stay put. What is more, Israeli bombing continues in southern Gaza as well, with reports of refugees from the north being killed in air strikes. A common refrain among Gazans is that nowhere in the territory is safe, and that they might as well stay in the relative comfort of their homes.

Another worry for Israel's generals is the risk of a war on two fronts. Iran, an ally of Hamas, was caught by surprise on October 7th, according to people familiar with the situation. But it has since urged Hizbullah, a big militant group in Lebanon, to enter the fray. Hizbullah has an arsenal of some 150,000 rockets and missiles, including more accurate ones than Hamas can deploy, which would severely tax Israel's missile-defence systems.

The possibility of war with Hizbullah is looking likelier by the day, say Israeli insiders. Although Hizbullah might prefer not to invite Israeli retaliation against Lebanon, which is gripped by a dire economic slump, it ultimately answers to its Iranian paymasters, not ordinary Lebanese. On October 16th Hossein Amir-Abdollahian, Iran's foreign minister, made an ominous warning: “The possibility of pre-emptive action…is expected in the coming hours,” he told Iranian state television. The same day Israel's government issued an unprecedented order to evacuate 28 Israeli villages within 2km of the border with Lebanon. On October 17th the IDF killed four people attempting to cross a security fence.

Some ministers and defence officials have suggested that it may be better for Israel to attack Hizbullah pre-emptively, rather than wait for another surprise attack, this time from the north. Israel's war cabinet, which includes both Binyamin Netanyahu, the prime minister, and various political rivals, including former generals, seems inclined to wait while sending more troops to the border.

Israel may also be waiting for more American firepower to arrive in the region. A flotilla led by an aircraft-carrier is already in the eastern Mediterranean. Another is en route. These forces are intended to deter Iran, Hizbullah and other Iran-aligned militias in Iraq, Syria and Yemen from entering the war, or attacking American interests in the Gulf. The American ships' air-defence systems may also be able to provide Israel with additional warning of missile strikes, if not a degree of protection.

Another potential disruption to Israel's preparations for war is the West Bank, the other slice of Palestinian territory, with roughly 2.7m inhabitants. The 40% of it that Israel does not administer directly are in the hands of the PA . But Mr Abbas is weak and unpopular. After the tragedy at the Ahli Arab hospital widespread protests broke out against his government. The IDF ’s fear is not so much of a third front, in the form of a popular uprising against Israel, so much as chaos that requires the presence of more Israeli troops. There is also the constant threat of violence between Palestinians and the almost 700,000 Israeli settlers in the West Bank and the eastern part of Jerusalem.

A final reason for Israel to delay its offensive was an effort to free at least some of the Israeli hostages captured on October 7th. The IDF believes that Hamas, Islamic Jihad and other groups hold 203 of them. Israeli spies have been trying to gather intelligence about where they are being held.

Discussions disrupted

Quiet talks to secure the release of hostages had been under way. Qatar, which hosts Hamas's political leadership and has strong ties to the group, had been acting as a go-between. But those diplomatic efforts appeared to collapse on October 17th after the tragedy at the Ahli Arab hospital. Most Arab states, including those who had previously appeared somewhat sympathetic to Israel, such as the United Arab Emirates, blamed the IDF for the disaster, despite Israel's detailed disavowal of responsibility. That both makes it much harder for Israel to build diplomatic support for a ground war and gives it less reason to delay, now that Mr Biden has left the region.

Israeli commanders, at any rate, are getting itchy feet. The IDF began mustering within hours of the atrocities of October 7th. Its forces have been largely in place for almost a week.“We really should get going this weekend,” says a colonel. “You can maintain this level of readiness for two weeks at the most.”

The invasion, when it comes, will be hard-fought and bloody. Israel's leaders have loudly and repeatedly promised to destroy Hamas's military capabilities for good and end its 16-year rule. That means a campaign of a different order from previous incursions into Gaza, in 2009 and 2014, which aimed merely to diminish Hamas's military capacity and were followed by a gradual return to the status quo.

But the Gaza Strip is a difficult place to fight, for several reasons. First, it is full of dense cities, composed of tightly packed apartment blocks. Such places will limit the invaders' lines of sight and hamper their communications, with the tall buildings impeding radio signals. Civilians could be anywhere, and there will be endless places for Hamas's fighters to hide.

What is more, Hamas has built a 500km network of tunnels under Gaza—a territory only 40km long and 10km wide. The intention was in part to undercut Israel's technological advantage in seeing and striking from the air. Even the most sophisticated drones cannot provide much information about what is happening underground. Troops entering the tunnels cannot navigate by GPS or communicate by radio.

In its invasion of Gaza in 2014 the IDF struggled to deal with such tunnels. It has since invested heavily in subterranean warfare, setting up special units for the task and constructing a simulacrum of Hamas tunnels for training. It has developed various technical means to hunt for them, including some modelled on the underground surveys conducted by the oil industry, as well as methods based on old-fashioned intelligence—looking for spots where militants' mobile-phone signals suddenly disappear, for instance. Even so, finding and demolishing the tunnel network will be the work of months, if not years, and certainly not a few days.

A second concern is the presence of so many Palestinian civilians. American-led assaults on cities during the Iraq war and the Iraqi-led, Western-backed capture of Mosul from Islamic State in 2016-17, were painstakingly planned and conducted with the benefit of copious intelligence. Large numbers of civilians died nonetheless—perhaps as many as 10,000 in the battle for Mosul alone.

In theory, international humanitarian law, which governs the conduct of armies once they are waging a war, demands that soldiers distinguish between combatants and military objects on the one hand and civilians and civilian objects on the other. Targeting those on purpose is always illegal. But an attack that kills civilians—even lots of them—can be legal if it is necessary for some military purpose and proportionate “in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated”. In other words, Israel can legally justify the deaths of civilians as long as they are killed in the crossfire in operations that did not use disproportionate force.

Whatever international law might say, however, as civilian casualties mount, so will pressure on Israel to withdraw and accept a ceasefire. Its previous invasions of Gaza, in 2009 and 2014, were quite brief. In both cases, the IDF remained on the ground for about 18 days. That would not be nearly enough time to achieve Israel's stated goals this time around. It took Iraqi troops nine months of house-to-house combat to subdue Mosul.

That points to perhaps the biggest challenge for Israeli forces in Gaza: not getting bogged down. America's invasions of Afghanistan and Iraq after the terrorist attacks of 9/11 and Israel's war in Lebanon in 1982 (the last time all those tanks were deployed) provide cautionary tales.

美国的“全球反恐战争”胜利打响。 2001年9月基地组织袭击美国仅两个月后，美国领导的部队就控制了阿富汗首都喀布尔。塔利班政府已经不复存在了。基地组织遭到追捕。其领导人奥萨马·本·拉登 (Osama bin Laden) 于 2011 年被追踪到巴基斯坦并被击毙。但塔利班却与日益壮大的叛乱活动作斗争。美国在失去 2,400 多名军事人员后于 2021 年撤离。阿富汗政府几乎立即垮台，塔利班重新掌权。

伊拉克战争也是不光彩的，而且更加血腥。 2003年4月，美国军队再次迅速占领首都巴格达。布什总统在亚伯拉罕·林肯号航空母舰的飞行甲板上昂首阔步，上面写着“任务完成”。事实上，该国即将陷入内战。美军抓获了伊拉克独裁者萨达姆·侯赛因，但很快就面临逊尼派和什叶派民兵的血腥叛乱。总共，美国失去了大约 4,500 名军人，更不用说大约 30 万伊拉克人死亡，其中大多数是平民。

A nti-monopoly cases have been known to reshape corporate America. In 1984 at & t ’s telephone network was found to have excluded competing firms. The company was controversially broken up in a move that ultimately led to a boom in innovation among its rivals. Meanwhile, a case against Microsoft in 1998 may have kept the door open for Google's subsequent rise. Microsoft had bundled together its Internet Explorer browser with its Windows operating system, and made other browsers more difficult to install. Some business historians think the case, by stopping this practice, made life easier for new browsers. It may also have distracted Microsoft from developing its own search engine.

Today, two big cases could redefine the limits of monopolies in the internet age. On September 12th America's Department of Justice ( d o j ) began its court battle against Google over the firm's deals to obtain default status on phones and browsers. On September 26th the Federal Trade Commission ( ftc ), chaired by Lina Khan, sued Amazon for allegedly penalising third-party sellers that offered lower prices on other sites, among other harmful practices. In both cases, the government thinks the tech giants are so dominant that their attempts to preserve market power are suspect. This raises a question: what counts as anticompetitive?

Historically, practices that might be ignored for a startup have not been tolerated in a dominant firm. John Rockefeller's Standard Oil was broken up in 1911, in part for striking deals with railroads that made it impossible for other oil firms to compete. Antitrust historians still debate the extent to which these deals were abusive—after all, Standard Oil benefited from economies of scale and bulk orders commonly receive discounts. But its size and bargaining power led to scrutiny. Before the firm's break-up, it had cornered 90% of oil refineries. Microsoft's bundling was found to be problematic because it had over 90% of the market for operating systems on personal computers. In both cases, the courts believed that dominant firms had made life too difficult for newcomers.

Today's cases have echoes of those past. Start with Google. It pays more than $10bn to Apple and other companies to be the default search engine on their platforms. The d o j argues this creates a barrier to entry for competitors. Because having lots of data lets a search engine show users more tailored advertisements, a dominant search engine has a larger expected ad revenue from an extra user. The twist is that if a smaller competitor happened to grow, it would be willing to pay more for additional users, thus bidding up how much Google would have to pay—and explaining why Google may be willing to pay large sums to prevent rivals from gaining a foothold. Yet it is easier to use a different search engine on an iPhone than it was to download a new browser on Windows. And Microsoft's dominance in operating systems seems to have been greater than Google's is in search. So the case is not airtight.

The case against Amazon is stronger. Luigi Zingales of the University of Chicago thinks that if the alleged facts are found to hold, the ftc should win. Sellers complain that Amazon penalises them for offering cheaper prices on other platforms by downranking products or removing them from the “Buy Box”, which allows instant purchases. Antitrust scholars call practices that force sellers to behave similarly across platforms “most-favoured-nation” ( mfn ) treatment, and they have come under growing scrutiny. In the past Amazon has had explicit mfn contracts with sellers.

The problem, according to the ftc , is that Amazon has raised the cost of doing business on its platform. It charges sellers a fee for selling, one for using its logistics services and more for advertising. Sellers say that it is next to impossible to qualify for the Buy Box without paying for logistics, and that buying ads has become a must because search results are increasingly cluttered with them. Although the exact figures are redacted, regulators allege that Amazon now collects a larger share of sales on its marketplace as fees than it did a decade ago. In a competitive market, Amazon's cost hikes and restrictions on pricing more cheaply elsewhere would cause sellers to leave the platform. And in fact, some large retailers, like Nike, have done so. But Amazon's market share in e-commerce has grown (it currently stands at 40-50% in America), suggesting most sellers feel that the platform is too important to quit.

Amazon denies all this. As with Google, there is a chance that the case becomes a debate about how dominant the firm really is (Amazon argues that it is dwarfed by the multitude of brick-and-mortar stores). American retail is efficient and broadly consumer-friendly—hardly the sign of an industry in need of repair. Amazon also says that if a seller can offer a lower price on another platform, it should do so on its site, too. One can imagine a seller thinking that Amazon Prime customers are rich and price insensitive, and therefore charging more on Amazon than other platforms.

Ready for a remedy

But if that is the case, Amazon has plenty of options available, says Fiona Scott Morton, formerly of the d o j . Imagine, for example, that Amazon thinks that the seller of a particular item is charging too much. It is free to prioritise other sellers of that item in its search results. If it cannot find any on its platform, it can recruit one from outside. If it still cannot find one, then perhaps Amazon is simply an expensive platform on which to do business.

In this final case, a possible solution is a so-called behavioural remedy, in which Amazon is made to stop penalising sellers that offer lower prices elsewhere. In Europe, where Amazon has also faced scrutiny, the company has made several concessions, including treating all sellers the same when granting access to the much sought-after Buy Box. Ms Khan of the ftc has said she does not like remedies that only target the behaviour of companies, since they are at best short-term fixes when set against more drastic measures, like breaking them up. Sometimes, however, nothing more is needed than a slap on the wrist. ■

H ow rapidly things fall apart. The deadly blast in Gaza at Ahli Arab hospital on the evening of October 17th killed many Palestinians who were taking shelter. Despite strong evidence that their deaths were caused by the failure of a Palestinian rocket laden with fuel, Arab countries rushed to condemn Israel. Hizbullah , a heavily armed Lebanese militia, is lurching closer to outright war with Israel. Bridges built painstakingly between Israel and its Arab neighbours lie in ruins.

How fragile are the forces trying to hold things together. Fifteen hours after the blast, President Joe Biden landed in Israel, an old man with the weight of the world on his shoulders. Mr Biden's diplomacy is a geopolitical moment. As well as signalling grief and support for Israel, it brings into focus how much this crisis matters to the Middle East and to America .

For the past half-century the United States has been the only country willing and able to bring any kind of order to the region. Regardless of the many failures of American policy there, including in Iraq and Syria, Mr Biden and his secretary of state, Antony Blinken, have once again taken up that burden. Death and disease hang over Gaza. The poison is spreading across the Arab world. They do not have long.

The imminent danger is on that second front in the north of Israel. The death toll at Ahli Arab means that Hizbullah and its Iranian sponsors risk losing face if they fail to avenge lost Palestinian lives. Hizbullah will now also have strong backing in the Arab world if it attacks. If Israel concludes war is inevitable, it may strike first. America has tasked two aircraft-carriers with deterring Hizbullah and Iran from opening a second front. If they defy it, it should use them for a show of force.

A second danger is of Arab-Israeli relations being put back decades. Amid Israel's unprecedented bombing, Arabs remember previous wars in which Israel hit schools and hospitals. Israel has imposed a total siege of Gaza; its president has said all Gazans share responsibility. Despite Israel's excesses, Arab leaders could have called for calm and for an independent investigation of the hospital blast. What looks like the mass killing of Palestinians by Palestinians ought to have redoubled their efforts to safeguard Gaza's civilians and spurred them on to create a regional plan for a better Palestinian future.

Instead, the blast has deepened hatred and grievances. In words that cannot easily be taken back, Israel's Arab partners heaped blame upon the Jewish state. Jordan immediately cancelled a summit between Mr Biden and Arab leaders that had been the best hope for regional diplomacy. Egypt is more resolved than ever to keep temporary refugees out of the Sinai, partly for fear of being seen to abet Israel in what Palestinians worry is a plan to empty Gaza permanently.

This is a lamentable failure of leadership, with profound regional and global implications. Most Arab governments loathe Hamas and its backer, Iran. Countries like the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia need stability and benefit from good relations with Israel. However, they are so wary of testing their citizens' anger with the truth about the rocket's origin that they have chosen to sabotage their people's long-term interests.

For Iran, that looks like victory. For years it has had a strategy of financing, arming and training proxies like Hamas and Hizbullah. It calculates that violence and mayhem weaken Israel and discredit Arab governments. If the sight of America fighting Hizbullah alongside Israel leads to a rupture of Mr Biden's relations with the Arab world, an exultant Iran will have built the foundations for its own regional dominance.

Russia and China are winning, too. There is a perception in the global south that this complex story is actually a simple one of oppressed Palestinians and Israeli colonisers. China and Russia will exploit this caricature to argue that America is revealing its true contempt for brown-skinned people in Gaza and its hypocrisy over human rights and war crimes—just as they claim it did by supposedly provoking a war in Ukraine.

What can Mr Biden do? His analysis must start with the need for peace between the Palestinians and Israelis and a recognition that there can be none for as long as Hamas governs Gaza—not after it has demonstrated that it puts Jew-hatred before any other goal. Gaza City is honeycombed by tunnels. Destroying Hamas's ability to wage war therefore requires a ground offensive.

Everything follows from the prosecution of that ground war. The tragedy of Ahli Arab validates the cynical calculation that Palestinian casualties help Hamas by undermining support for Israel. The Israeli army needs to be seen to spare civilians, not least because it needs time to destroy Hamas's tunnels. Gaza is on the brink. Poor sanitation threatens epidemic disease. Israel has at last agreed that some aid can cross into Gaza. Much more will be needed. If Egypt continues to bar refugees, Israel should go further by creating havens on its own territory in the Negev, supervised by UN agencies.

It is also vital to spell out what comes after the invasion. Israel needs to show that its fight is with the terrorists, not the people of Gaza. It should pledge a new beginning after the war, with a programme of rebuilding and the promise that it will not strangle Gaza's economy. It should support a new Palestinian constitution and new elected leaders. All this would be easier under a new Israeli government voted in when the war is done.

Even if Mr Biden can persuade Israel to take these steps, that leaves the hardest question of all. How to provide security in post-Hamas Gaza? Israel cannot occupy the enclave permanently. That idea was rightly abandoned in 2005. An international commitment is therefore needed. Because it is not clear who would join this, Mr Biden should start building a coalition now. The more Israel shows the Arab world that it is serious about protecting civilians and planning for the day after, the more likely Arab leaders are to play their part.

This is a tall order. Much can and will go wrong. Ordinary Arabs' ingrained anti-Zionism will gnaw at their leaders' willingness to help. But the alternative is the decay that feeds scavenger states like Iran and Russia. Mr Biden is the only leader who can pull things back together. If he fails, and the security of the Middle East crumbles, it will be a catastrophe for America, too. ■

; Thu, 19 Oct 2023 09:33:29 GMT /content/p5huijmr7qa1otelgbbh4nuiultvp8h9 https://www.economist.com/leaders/2023/10/19/the-stakes-could-hardly-be-higher-in-the-israel-gaza-conflict Why America’s banks need more capital

A MERICA SPENT more than a decade trying to make its banks safer, only for several of them to collapse suddenly earlier this year. So it is no surprise that regulators are trying once again to shore up the system. Their latest proposals would on average increase by 16% the amount of high-quality equity capital banks would need to fund their operations, among a litany of other changes designed to bring America's rules in line with principles agreed globally. If the package—dubbed the “Basel 3 endgame”—is implemented, banks, which have been reporting their profits over the past week, will have to spend years building up their safety buffers.

Bankers are furious. “What person in what ivory tower thinks that is a rational thing to do?” asked Jamie Dimon, the boss of JPMorgan Chase, of one of the rule changes last month. Some of the industry's complaints about the details are reasonable. Overall, however, the increased safety brought about by more capital is worth the costs.

The benefits of the reform are most obvious for the type of bank that has been vulnerable this year. Silicon Valley Bank ( svb ), which had $212bn in assets, collapsed in March having suffered enormous losses on its bond portfolio as interest rates rose. As a bank with assets of less than $700bn, it was exempt from having to mark its bond portfolio to market when calculating its safety buffer, even if those bonds were categorised as holdings that may be sold (rather than held until they mature). Only when depositors fled from SVB, forcing it to sell bonds at a loss, was its capital cushion revealed to be an accounting fiction. The new proposal lowers the asset threshold to $100bn, requiring banks of SVB' s size to value accurately at least some of their bonds. As a result many will have to build up capital, which should help prevent a repeat of the debacle.

For the biggest banks, the argument is less clear-cut. They did not suffer during the spring crisis, and instead hoovered up deposits that fled from smaller institutions. They are considerably better capitalised than they were a decade ago. And because their depositors remain loyal even if they don't pay much interest, higher rates have served mainly to boost their profits by raising the amount they can charge on loans. In earnings reports released since October 13th JPMorgan, Bank of America and Citigroup all recorded rising net interest margins in the third quarter of 2023, fitting a pattern whereby the larger the bank, the more likely it has been to benefit from higher interest rates.

Capital also comes with downsides. It is a more expensive means of funding loans than debt or deposits, and some of those costs get passed on to borrowers. Some of the new rules might make financial intermediation in important markets harder. If regulators neglect shadier parts of the financial system, activity could migrate there to escape their scrutiny. Mr Dimon is right that some of the new edicts are poorly designed.

Yet the move towards bigger safety buffers is nonetheless desirable. The big banks did not collapse in the spring, but it is they whose failure would cause an economic catastrophe—and, probably, land taxpayers with the biggest bail-out costs. By one estimate the global financial crisis of 2007-09 cost every American $70,000 in income over their lifetimes. So painful are banking crashes that studies which attempt to weigh the costs and benefits of capital often call for a much fatter cushion than would be in place even if the Basel 3 endgame is implemented.

It is no surprise that bankers object to more capital, which is rather like being forced to buy insurance against unlikely events. But society as a whole benefits enormously when that insurance is in place. The strength of America's economy means that now is a good time to try to make the system safer, because building safety buffers is harder than maintaining them.

Even if the proposals are enacted, America's banking woes are far from over. The simplest way to build capital is to retain profits rather than pay them out in dividends. Yet many small banks are enduring a profit squeeze, because they are having to pay more interest to retain depositors, or now depend on short-term borrowing at the prevailing high rate of interest. Use of a supposedly temporary emergency lending programme at the Federal Reserve, for example, has crept up over the summer. The facility has outstanding balances of $109bn.

Bond portfolios also continue to shrink in value. By the end of July, banks' unrealised securities losses were worth $558bn; since then, long-term bonds have sold off further as investors have bet on interest rates staying higher for longer, reducing the chance of a reprieve. For many banks the best path to viability will be to find another institution willing to gobble them up. The system that emerges will be more concentrated. Regulators are right to seek to make it less fragile, too. ■

; Thu, 19 Oct 2023 09:29:17 GMT /content/acib0a8vu7ir5chqd55ghs1s7l2eu381 https://www.economist.com/leaders/2023/10/19/why-americas-banks-need-more-capital Amal Clooney and Rupert Skilbeck on why Britain fails to hold war criminals to account

I N THE YEAR and a half since Russia invaded Ukraine, Britain has repeatedly condemned Vladimir Putin's illegal act of aggression. It has taken action at the UN, frozen $23bn in Russian assets, imposed sanctions on 1,550 individuals, referred the conflict to the International Criminal Court ( ICC ) and donated £1m ($1.2m) to support its investigation. But what would the British authorities do if a Russian general who has committed crimes against humanity in Ukraine showed up at London's Heathrow airport? Would he be arrested and put on trial? The answer, unfortunately, is no.

British law recognises a principle known as universal jurisdiction, which permits the courts of any country to hold trials for a handful of offences—such as genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes—that “shock the conscience of mankind”, no matter where they occur. But legal and practical challenges have meant that only three people have ever been convicted of such crimes in Britain, with the last conviction secured almost 20 years ago.

The three successful cases resulted in convictions of individuals accused of torture in Afghanistan, war crimes in Iraq, and a Nazi who murdered 18 Jews. And they provided meaningful justice to victims. Indeed, since the ICC does not have jurisdiction over all conflicts, such trials can be the only way for perpetrators to be held to account. But when it comes to bringing such cases, Britain lags far behind countries such as Germany and France that have recently taken war criminals off their streets and put them on trial, securing convictions of Islamic State fighters for crimes against humanity, henchmen of Bashar al-Assad, Syria's dictator, for torture, and Rwandan fighters for genocide.

Britain has traditionally been at the forefront of international justice efforts, dating back to the Nuremberg trials, when it played a leading role in prosecuting Nazi commanders after the Holocaust. It has supported UN -sponsored courts following conflicts in Yugoslavia, Rwanda, Sierra Leone, Lebanon and Cambodia. It was a founding member of the ICC . It has a world-class judicial system, talented investigators and experienced lawyers who practise before international courts. Its leaders profess a commitment to justice for war crimes all over the world. So why has it fallen behind other advanced countries in prosecuting them?

The answer lies in three obstacles, all of them domestic. First, Britain does not allow prosecutions for most international crimes unless the suspect is a British national or resident. This keeps Russian generals and Iranian mullahs out of the reach of the British police. For a long time America had a similar limitation in its laws, but this was removed last year, allowing its courts to prosecute any state's nationals for war crimes if there is evidence that warrants a trial. When the law was reformed, Merrick Garland, the US attorney-general, commented that “in the United States of America, there must be no hiding place for war criminals and no safe haven for those who commit such atrocities”. Britain should be no different.

The second obstacle is inertia. The British authorities have typically waited too long to start an investigation and to gather admissible evidence from witnesses. In the German cases against Islamic State fighters, the investigation started before specific defendants were identified, and the testimony of Yazidi women who were captured by the fighters was pivotal. Similarly, British police should not wait for a suspect to enter Britain before starting their work, and they should let survivors know how to submit evidence that can be used in trials against their abusers.

Finally, Britain has traditionally granted “special mission immunity” to foreign officials visiting the country, without a carve-out for individuals suspected by police or the ICC of committing international crimes. This get-out-of-jail-free card should no longer be handed out in a way that undermines Britain's international obligations and commitment to the rule of law.

Britain has assumed a leading role in responding to the war in Ukraine. But condemnation and financial sanctions are not enough; it must also hold trials of alleged perpetrators within its borders. Britain showed that such trials were possible when it arrested General Augusto Pinochet, a former Chilean president, on charges of torture. But that was 25 years ago. As the world watches the horrors of war unfold in Ukraine, the Middle East and elsewhere, now is the time for Britain to live up to its principles and its history and ensure that, far from being a haven, its shores are hostile territory for war criminals. ■

Amal Clooney is a barrister at Doughty Street Chambers in London and co-founder of the Clooney Foundation for Justice. Rupert Skilbeck is a barrister and director of Redress, a human-rights organisation. (The Economist's editor-in-chief, Zanny Minton Beddoes, is on the board of the Clooney Foundation for Justice.)

随着时间的推移，以色列的边界发生了怎样的变化？为什么巴勒斯坦自治领土最终分散在两个不同的地区？地图上不断变化的线条有助于解释圣地阿拉伯人和犹太人之间一个多世纪的冲突。我们的解释从 1916 年开始（参见地图 1）。

第一次世界大战期间，英国外交官马克·赛克斯爵士和法国外交官弗朗索瓦·乔治·皮科被两国政府任命秘密瓜分奥斯曼帝国的土地。阿拉伯省份将被欧洲列强瓜分。鉴于巴勒斯坦在基督教、伊斯兰教和犹太教中的重要性，它被视为国际领土。 1917年英国发表《贝尔福宣言》，表示支持“在巴勒斯坦建立犹太人民的民族家园”。那时，犹太人在巴勒斯坦的农业定居点已经开始，由西奥多·赫茨尔 (Theodor Herzl) 创立的犹太复国主义运动在 1897 年于巴塞尔举行的第一次代表大会上宣布其目标是建立一个犹太人的家园。

1920年的圣雷莫会议最终确定了奥斯曼帝国的瓜分。英国被授权统治赛克斯-皮科设想的部分国际领土。次年再次分裂为巴勒斯坦和外约旦（哈希姆统治下的阿拉伯王国）。该授权由联合国前身国际联盟于 1922 年批准。重要的是，它包括对《贝尔福宣言》的支持。居住在那里的阿拉伯人越来越多地对占领者和越来越多的犹太移民（包括逃离纳粹迫害的德国犹太人）采取暴力。 1936年，阿拉伯人起义。英国镇压了起义，但试图通过限制犹太人在该地区的野心来赢得阿拉伯人的支持。犹太激进组织开始发动自己的叛乱，并在第二次世界大战后蔓延。最终英国人放弃了，并将问题移交给联合国。

大屠杀之后，国际社会承认犹太国家的压力越来越大。 1947年，联合国提议将巴勒斯坦分为三部分：阿拉伯国家、犹太国家和耶路撒冷，其目的是成为一个独立的实体，或一个独立的、国际运作的实体。暴力只会更加恶化。 1948 年英国完成撤军后，犹太领导人宣布以色列建国。邻近的阿拉伯国家迅速入侵。

以色列在阿拉伯入侵中幸存下来。 1949 年停战协定中，一条分界线（称为“绿线”）成为以色列和阿拉伯国家之间事实上的边界，尽管阿拉伯政府拒绝承认以色列。超过 70 万巴勒斯坦阿拉伯人逃离或被赶出家园。他们称之为“ nakba” ，即灾难。加沙地带和西岸分别受埃及和外约旦（后来的约旦）控制。耶路撒冷被分裂。

1967年，在以色列与阿拉伯邻国之间为期六天的战争中，以色列占领了约旦河西岸、东耶路撒冷、加沙地带、戈兰高地和西奈半岛。它吞并了东耶路撒冷和西岸的一部分，并在被占领的土地上建立了犹太人定居点。

1973年10月，犹太教圣日赎罪日，埃及和叙利亚对西奈半岛和戈兰高地发动袭击。在美国的主持下，以色列和埃及于 1978 年签署了《戴维营协议》，并于次年签署了和平条约。以色列同意归还整个西奈半岛，并给予巴勒斯坦人自治权。愤怒的阿拉伯国家将埃及踢出了阿拉伯联盟，巴勒斯坦自治也没有取得任何进展。

1987 年，巴勒斯坦人起义，发起了一场持续的罢工和投掷石块抗议运动，被称为第一次起义。 1993年，以色列和巴勒斯坦解放组织签署了第一份奥斯陆协议，规定巴勒斯坦民族权力机构（PA）在西岸和加沙地带享有为期五年的自治权。临时安排在西岸和加沙地带造成了混乱：在 A 区，巴勒斯坦权力机构获得了全面的民事和安全控制；在B区，它拥有民事事务和一些治安权力，但以色列保留最终的安全控制权；在C区，以色列完全控制。该协议将耶路撒冷和定居点的最终地位留待稍后解决。在2000年至2005年持续的第二次起义期间，巴勒斯坦人使用枪支和自杀式炸弹，以色列在约旦河西岸修建了安全屏障，并最终从加沙地带撤出了军队和定居者。在约旦河西岸，它撤出了四个定居点。

如今，近 300 万巴勒斯坦人生活在约旦河西岸，超过 45 万以色列人生活在定居点（不包括东耶路撒冷），这一数字自奥斯陆协议签署以来大约增长了四倍。一些定居者现已在西岸生活了两代人。 Jerusalem is ringed with settlements.加沙的巴勒斯坦人的处境比其他地方的巴勒斯坦人要糟糕得多。自2007年以来，该地区一直由激进组织哈马斯控制。哈马斯上台后，埃及和以色列加强了对该地区的封锁。哈马斯武装分子和以色列现已交战五次。最近的战斗是迄今为止最致命的一次。■
